page.title: Unit 4 Overview: Why Should I Care?
page.contents:
Do you know what a budget is? Have you ever used one? Watch the video to learn a bit about how City Manager Arthur Noriega uses linear equations to manage the budget for the city of Miami.



In this unit, you will learn about linear equations. Understanding how to write, solve, and graph linear equations can help you with personal budgeting, whether you want to know how soon you’ll be able to save for a new bicycle or if you can afford to go to a concert with your friends in two weeks.

Building Character: Creativity

As a city manager, Arthur Noriega must work with others to develop budgets. Similarly, in this course, you will need to work with your classmates to solve problems. Working well with others is a skill that will be useful to you in this course, as well as outside the classroom. Most jobs require the ability to work well, or collaborate, with other people.

Throughout this unit, you will work on developing your social intelligence. Social intelligence is the ability to connect with other people. Having this ability allows you to interact in a more positive manner with others. Being empathetic, or sensitive to what others are feeling, shows that you care about others. In fact, empathetic people are less likely to experience anxiety, depression, and addictions later in life. They are also more likely to be hired, promoted, earn more money, and have happier marriages and better-adjusted children.

Think about your current sense of social intelligence. How many of the following statements are true for you?

  • I have a lot of relationships that are mutually beneficial, enjoyable, and supportive.
  • Most of the time, I can tell how other people feel and have a good idea about how to respond appropriately.
  • My relationships make me feel good about myself.
  • The people in my life help me be my best.

Don’t worry if none of these statements are true for you. Developing this trait takes time. Your first step starts today!

  • Use a pattern to find the next term in a sequence.

Next, you will answer some questions that will help you see how ready you are for this unit. If you need help, some mini-lessons will help you brush up on anything you need to work on.

page.title: Question #1: Find Slope
page.contents: What is the slope of the line that goes through points \(A\) and \(D\)?

answer.answer_text: 2
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Substitute the coordinates of points \(A(2, 3)\) and \(D(-1, -3)\) into the slope formula: \(m= \frac{-3-3}{-1-2} = 2\).

answer.answer_text: –2
answer.response: Incorrect. First, identify the coordinates of points \(A(2, 3)\) and \(D(-1, -3)\). Then substitute –3 for \(y_2\), 3 for \(y_1\), –1 for \(x_2\), and 2 for \(x_1\) in the slope formula \(m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\). Watch the signs when subtracting. The slope is \(m= \frac{-3-3}{-1-2} = 2\). The correct answer is 2.

answer.answer_text: \(\frac12\)
answer.response: Incorrect. First, identify the coordinates of points \(A(2, 3)\) and \(D(-1, -3)\). Be sure to substitute the \(y\)-values in the numerator and the \(x\)-values in the denominator of the slope formula. Substitute –3 for \(y_2\), 3 for \(y_1\), –1 for \(x_2\), and 2 for \(x_1\) in the slope formula \(m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\). The slope is \(m= \frac{-3-3}{-1-2} = 2\). The correct answer is 2.

answer.answer_text: \(-\frac12\)
answer.response: Incorrect. First, identify the coordinates of points \(A(2, 3)\) and \(D(-1, -3)\). Be sure to substitute the \(y\)-values in the numerator and the \(x\)-values in the denominator of the slope formula. Substitute –3 for \(y_2\), 3 for \(y_1\), –1 for \(x_2\), and 2 for \(x_1\) in the slope formula \(m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\). Watch the signs when subtracting. The slope is \(m= \frac{-3-3}{-1-2} = 2\). The correct answer is 2.

page.title: Find Slope: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Find the Slope of a Line Using Points on a Graph

The slope of a line is the ratio of the change in \(y\) and the change in \(x\). You can use the slope formula, \(m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\), to find the slope of the line through points \((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\).

Find the slope of the line that goes through points 

  1. \(A\) and \(D\)
  2. \(A\) and \(B\)
  3. \(C\) and \(D\)

Here’s how to find the slope given two points.

  1.  

First, name \(B(-3, -4)\) as point 1 and \(D(4, 3)\) as point 2.

\((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\)

\((-3, -4)\) and \((4, 3)\)

Use the slope formula.

\(m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\)

Substitute the values: \(y_2 = -3\), \(y_1 = 3\), \(x_2 = -1\), \(x_1 = 2\).

\(m= \frac{-3-3}{-1-2}\)

Simplify.

\(m= \frac{-6}{-3}\)

\(m= 2\)

  1.  

First, name \(A(2, 3)\) as point 1 and \(B(4, -1)\) as point 2.

\((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\)

\((2, 3)\) and \((4, -1)\)

Use the slope formula.

\(m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\)

Substitute the values: \(y_2 = -1\), \(y_1 = 3\), \(x_2 = 4\), \(x_1 = 2\).

\(m= \frac{-1-3}{4-2}\)

Simplify.

\(m= \frac{-4}{2}\)

\(m= -2\)

  1.  

First, name \(C(-2, 5)\) as point 1 and \(D(-1, -3)\) as point 2.

\((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\)

\((-2, 5)\) and \((-1, -3)\)

Use the slope formula.

\(m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\)

Substitute the values: \(y_2 = -3\), \(y_1 = 5\), \(x_2 = -1\), \(x_1 = -2\).

\(m= \frac{-3-5}{-1-(-2)}\)

Simplify.

\(m= \frac{-8}{1}\)

\(m= -8\)

Try It: Find the Slope of a Line Using Points on a Graph

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the slope given two points:


First, name \(B(-3, -4)\) as point 1 and \(D(4, 3)\) as point 2.

\((x_1, y_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2)\)

\((-3, -4)\) and \((4, 3)\)

Use the slope formula.

\(m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\)

Substitute the values: \(y_2 = 3\), \(y_1 = -4\), \(x_2 = 4\), \(x_1 = -3\).

\(m=\frac{3-(-4)}{4-(-3)}\)

Simplify.

\(m=\frac 77\)

\(m= 1\)



Check Your Understanding

What is the slope of the line that goes through points \(A\) and \(D\)?

Correct! Check yourself: Substitute the coordinates of points \(A(-4, 2)\) and \(D(5, -1)\) into the slope formula: \(m= \frac{-1-2}{5-(-4)}=-\frac13\).

Incorrect. First, identify the coordinates of points \(A(-4, 2)\) and \((5, -1)\). Be sure to substitute the \(y\)-values in the numerator and the \(x\)-values in the denominator of the slope formula.

Check yourself: Substitute the coordinates of points \(A(-4, 2)\) and \(D(5, -1)\) into the slope formula: \(m= \frac{-1-2}{5-(-4)}=-\frac13\).

page.title: Question #2: Describe Graphs
page.contents: Which statement best describes the situation shown in the graph?

answer.answer_text: Mai begins her walk at school and walks home at a constant rate.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This description would match a graph where the distance from home is decreasing, so the line would have a negative slope. The \(y\)-intercept shows that she starts a short distance from home, and the line increases, showing she is moving away from home at a constant rate. The correct answer is Mai begins at a neighbor’s house and walks away from home at a constant rate.

answer.answer_text: Mai begins at home and walks away from her home at a constant rate.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This description would match a graph where the \(y\)-intercept is at the origin. Mai starts a short distance from home, and the line increases, showing she is moving away from home at a constant rate. The correct answer is Mai begins at a neighbor’s house and walks away from home at a constant rate.

answer.answer_text: Mai begins at a neighbor’s house and walks away from home at a constant rate.
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The \(y\)-intercept shows that she starts a short distance from home, and the line increases, showing she is moving away from home at a constant rate.

answer.answer_text: Mai begins at a neighbor’s house and runs away from home, and then walks for a while.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This description would match a graph that has a steeper slope for part of the time and then a less steep slope for the second part. The graph shows she is moving away at a constant rate. The correct answer is Mai begins at a neighbor’s house and walks away from home at a constant rate.

page.title: Describe Graphs: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Match a Description with a Graph

A graph can be used to model a situation. You can use what you know about slope and \(y\)-intercept to connect the graphs to real situations.  

  1.  



Match each description with one of the graphs above:

  1. Elena begins at home and runs away from her home at a constant rate. 

Elena starts at home, so the graph must start at the origin. She moves away from home at a constant speed, so the graph must be a line that increases to the right. Graph B matches the description.

  1. Clare begins her walk at school and walks home at a constant rate.

Clare starts at school, so the \(y\)-intercept is a point on the \(y\)-axis that shows the distance her home is from the school. She moves closer to home at a constant speed, so the graph must be a line that decreases to the right. Graph C matches the description. 

  1. Lin begins at home and runs away from home, and then walks for a while.

Lin starts at home, so the graph must start at the origin. She starts running and then walks, so the graph is a line with a slope that starts off steep and then continues with a less steep slope. Graph A matches the description.

Try It: Match a Description with a Graph

Describe the graph. You can use the wording from the previous problem as a guide.

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to describe the graph:

The graph starts at the origin, so the walker starts at home. The line is increasing, so the walker is moving at a constant speed away from home. Then the line decreases at a constant rate, so the walker is moving at a constant rate toward home. 

Here is a possible description:

Lin begins at home and walks away from home for a while, and then she walks back home.



Check Your Understanding

Which statement best describes the situation shown in the graph?


Correct! The y-intercept shows that he starts at a distance from home and moves at a constant rate to home. Then he walks away from home.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way.

Check yourself: The y-intercept shows that he starts at a distance from home and moves at a constant rate to home. Then he walks away from home.

page.title: Question #3: Extend a Pattern
page.contents:
Which describes the rule and the next two terms in the sequence?

2, 6, 18, 54, . . .

answer.answer_text: Multiply by 3; 162, 486
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Dividing consecutive terms results in the quotient 3. This means you multiply each term by 3 to get the next term.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The result of adding 4 to the first term, 2, is the second term, 6. The result of adding 4 to the second term, 6, is 10, not 18. The rule must work for each term. The correct answer is: Multiply by 3; 162, 486.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The result of dividing consecutive terms is 3. This means you multiply by 3 to get the next term, not add. The answer is: Multiply by 3; 162, 486.

answer.answer_text: Multiply by 4; 216, 864
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The result of subtracting the first two terms is 4. This might indicate a pattern of adding 4, not multiplying by 4. The answer is: Multiply by 3; 162, 486.

page.title: Extend a Pattern: Mini-Lesson Review
page.contents:
Use a Rule to Extend a Pattern

Pattern rules can use one or more mathematical operations to describe the relationship between consecutive numbers in a list of numbers, or sequence. Knowing the pattern rule will help you extend the pattern. To extend the pattern means to use the pattern rule to write the numbers that would come next in the sequence.

Try to see the difference between consecutive numbers. It will help you understand the relationship between the numbers.

Find the next two numbers in the following sequence:

3, 6, 9, 12, . . .

First, figure out the pattern rule. The numbers are increasing, so the rule likely involves addition or multiplication.

  • Look at the first two terms, 3 and 6. What operation could you perform on 3 to get 6?
    • You could add 3.
    • You could multiply by 2.
    • You could do a combination of two or more operations.
  • Look at the second two terms, 6 and 9.
    • If you add 3 to 6, you get 9. So the pattern rule “add 3” seems to work.
  • Make sure the pattern rule “add 3” works for every term.
    • \( 9 + 3 = 12\)

The pattern rule works. To extend the pattern, apply the pattern rule of “add 3” to the last term, 12, to get the next term, and then “add 3” to the result to get another term. The answer is that the extended pattern is:

3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, . . .

You can find a particular term in the pattern by extending the pattern until you’ve reached the term you are looking for.

What is the seventh number in the following sequence?

64, 32, 16, 8, . . .

First, figure out the pattern rule. The numbers are decreasing, so the rule likely involves subtraction or division.

  • Look at the first two terms, 64 and 32. What operation could you perform on 64 to get 32?
    • You could subtract 32.
    • You could divide by 2.
    • You could do a combination of two or more operations.
  • Look at the second two terms, 32 and 16.
    • If you subtract 32 from 32, you get 0, not 16. So the pattern rule “subtract 32” does not work.
    • If you divide 32 by 2, you get 16. So the pattern rule “divide by 2” seems to work.
  • Make sure the pattern rule “divide by 2” works for every term.
    • \(16\;\div\;2\;=\;8\)

The pattern rule works. To extend the pattern, apply the pattern rule of “divide by 2” to the last term, 8, to get the next term, and continue dividing by 2 until you reach the seventh term.

64, 32, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1

The seventh term of the sequence is 1.

Try It: Use a Rule to Extend a Pattern

Describe the rule and find the next two terms in the sequence.

3, 9, 27, 81, . . .

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here’s how to identify a rule to extend a pattern:

The numbers are increasing, so the rule likely involves addition or multiplication.

  • Look at the first two terms, 3 and 9. What operation could you perform on 3 to get 9?
    • You could add 6.
    • You could multiply by 3.
    • You could do a combination of two or more operations.
  • Look at the second two terms, 9 and 27.
    • If you add 6 to 9, you get 15, not 27. So the pattern rule “add 6” does not work.
    • If you multiply 9 by 3, you get 27. So the rule “multiply by 3” seems to work.
  • Make sure the pattern rule “multiply by 3” works for every term.
    • \(27\;\times\;3\;=\;81\)

The pattern rule works. To extend the pattern, apply the pattern rule of “multiply by 3” to the last term, 81, to get the next term, and then “multiply by 3” to the result to get another term. The answer is that the extended pattern is:

3, 9, 27, 81, 243, 729, . . .

The rule is “multiply by 3,” and the next two terms are 243 and 729.
